div1.p:

ORDERS, BOOKS, BLANKS & D.C. DIV.
A. G. O.
RECD. OCT 6 1900

FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Vol 247 A

HEADQUARTERS DEPT. OF WESTERN CUBA.
Quemados, September 24, 1900.

With profound sorrow the Department Commander
announces the death of Major George S. Cartwright,
Quartermaster, U. S. Volunteers (Captain 24th In-
fantry), which occurred at the hospital, Columbia
Barracks, on the 23d instant. Major Cartwright was
born in the State of New York and appointed to the
Military Academy from that state in 1881, graduating
in 1885. He was appointed 2d Lieutenant, 24th In-
fantry on the 14th of June of that year, 1st Lieut-
enant, 16th Infantry the 2d of April, 1892, transferred
to the 24th Infantry the 12th of August, 1892, and ap-
pointed captain, 24th Infantry, 2d of March, 1899.

Service in volunteers as follows: Captain and As-
sistant Quartermaster 19th of May, 1898; honorably
discharged 19th of June, 1899; Major and Quarter-
master 11th of July, 1899.

Major Cartwright served with distinction as an aid
on the staff of Brigadier General J. Ford Kent, U. S.
Volunteers, who commanded the 1st Division of the
5th Army Corps, at the battle of San Juan, in the
campaign against Santiago in July 1898.

He was assigned to the staff of the Department Com
mander as Chief Quartermaster on May 1, 1900, by
paragraph 31, Special Orders No. 102, current series,
Headquarters of the Army, Adjutant General's Office.

Stricken in the prime of manhood, the Army has
lost an excellent soldier and the Department a merit-
orious officer of inflexible integrity. Modest and unas-
suming in manner, always courteous and kind, his
friends were many and while his loss is irreparable,
their past association with this gallant officer will
remain to them a cherished memory.

The usual badge of mourning will be worn by
members of the Staff for thirty days.
BY COMMAND OF BRIGADIER GENERAL LEE:

R. E. L. MICHIE,
Assistant Adjutant General.
